Mark--
No need to apologize. I, too, have posted about the emotional toll the past few years of the tyranny of the minority has taken upon me. I realize, as do you, that this forum for comments is not meant to be a psychiatrist's couch. At the same time, it's appropriate to discuss in some measure the psychological trauma being inflicted upon us, which we seem powerless to stop. To say you are laid low is not indulgent. It's an appropriate response to the carnage around us.

Fact is, it's difficult to feel optimistic given the situation you so ably describe.

In general, if someone injures you or your family by negligent operation of his car, insurance means that your medical bills will be paid and your car will be fixed. In the event of your death your family will receive compensation. The principal reason for insurance is not to deter negligence but to provide a source of payment in the event of negligent or intentional harm. Your policy includes uninsured motorist coverage. (So you pay for the irresponsible people who drive without insurance.)

Because policy premiums increase as a result of risky behavior (accidents, DUIs, speeding tickets), there is some deterrent effect for insurance, because people want to avoid premium increases.

Requiring gun insurance possibly could reinforce safe gun handling practices (locked gun cabinets, training, etc.) which might cut down on stolen guns, gun accidents, etc, but that is not the primary purpose of such insurance. The primary purpose is to take steps to insure that victims of gun violence will have recourse against a solvent party.

To Bob Prentiss:

Those 700,000 jobs, to the extent they're not some fanciful number offered by those who wish to demonize the idea that we should spend only what we can afford to spend, nevertheless lie 100% in the public sector. If any job should be lost, it's one that DEPENDS on the private sector to pay for it and can't that should be lost, until we produce enough to be able to afford it again at current taxing levels.

Now, you can satisfy the requirements of the sequester by claiming that you must fire those folks if what you want to do it gin up resistance to cutting expenditures generally; or you could do it at least in part by telling government workers that they can't travel to Las Vegas and put on orgies masquerading as conferences, and similar secondary expenses. But it's so much better a cudgel when you want to scare people, rather than addressing a legitimate problem. Mr. Obama might call up a few of those businessmen he's been avoiding for years, and ask them what THEY do to lower costs by less than 2.5% of total spend -- they certainly don't START with laying people off.

Not surprisingly, the president's increasingly desperate concern that the sequester will be implemented is being taken up and energetically evangelized by the pundit liberati.

After all, by allowing spending CUTS, of all things, we might halt the inexorable advance toward government simply expropriating all production, then issuing food stamps, housing vouchers and entertainment chits to all Americans. And it was going so well ... and for the best of reasons.

But the sequester was a cynical gambit to allow Democrats to avoid the need to address the basic problems causing our debt to go off the rails -- ever-increasing spending on entitlements, eliminating the ability of Congress to address new challenges by reducing available discretionary spending. Mr. Obama's current desperation at the sequester falling in a few days is just unwillingness to accept that the days of free-spending are over.

And while Republicans' moves to limit damage to defense are quaint (and I don't support them), they're also meaningless: entitlement spending consumes more federal dollars than EVERYTHING else the feds spend on COMBINED: if we don't reduce the cost of social programs, then nothing we do in defense can make up for that failure. And forget about new taxes: we tax enough; we simply spend too much.

Across-the-board cuts are dumb; but in the absence of any ability of Congress to prioritize, it's what we're left with. We're out of available road for can-kicking. Bring on the sequester.

I may be naive, but I doubt the "sequester" will take place. I do not underestimate the power of your opinions and economic philosophy. They have proven to be correct. But is not the primary reason for my prediction. In the first place, the Republicans have followed a blueprint of negotiating at the last minute to get what they perceive to be the best deal, so waiting until now implies they will make a deal. Secondly, it becomes more obvious with every passing day that it is the Republicans who will take the blame if the sequester does happen. They will lose the House as they did in '96.  Thirdly, the consensus of the country is with the President over the Congress as shown by the polls in USA Today.  Fourth, Boehner hates the "Tea Party" and its consignees more than you or I do. They have embarrassed him on numerous occasions and he will be more than happy to stick it to them when the time comes. Finally, too many Republican patrons have too much to lose if it does happen. So if you were a betting man, I say long the market, long gold and long bonds, at least for the next two weeks.  You can send my commission to The City of Hope.

GOP: Government by ideology. Deals not allowed. Our way or the highway.

And what ideology is that? Government's function is to protect the wealth of the wealthy from any redistribution by ... government, rather than by private financial interests. It's an ideology reduced for the simple-minded by the simple-minded to six words: Don't raise taxes no matter what.

It is NOT about deficits. Spend money on two wars, okay, but don't raise taxes to pay for them, much less to educate someone else's child or to care for the sick, or to feed the poor. It's not a rational, consistent ideology, or one that can be shown to be rooted in experience or numbers. Deal with any evidence to the contrary (Tory policies in the UK for example) in the usual way: ignore it.

None of this ought to matter. After all, the GOP lost the presidency, lost the popular vote for the House, lost the Electoral College (a rough reflection of what would have happened if all Senate seats were up at one time). But majority rule has been replaced by Robert's Rules of Disorder in the Senate, Gerry's Manderdate in the House.

Fidelity to "majority rule" has been replaced by fidelity to plutocrat$: "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man ca$h in afterwards." The fact that the tyrannical minority can steer the ship of state onto economic shoals is a measure of the extent to which our Constitutional system has entirely broken down.

That is the real crisis, and it ain't going away anytime soon.

Additional Suggestions from a parent with 3 grown successful happy children
(1) Use body language, do not scream from a distance. Make eye contact at eye level with your child, put both hands on the child's shoulders, and communicate a simple, calm, firm message.
(2) Use distraction when your child is to upset to understand you. For example, when your child screams in the restaurant, get out of the chair and take a walk and look around. Later when your child is calm, you can talk.
(3) Don't threaten or negotiate, no second or third chances, use firm, calm, predictable, immediate punishment such as a time out, never physical punishment. Some parents feel uncomfortable punishing a child, but remember: undisciplined children grow up to become undisciplined unhappy adults. .
(4) Focus discipline on the important behaviors, behaviors related to safety, health, and necessary social skills.
